OPTIONS requests can respond with a "303 See Other" which could
point to =
a cacheable stand-alone, metadata document.
 
 

	-----Original Message----=
-
	From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...] 
	Sent: Tuesday, Janua=
ry 21, 2003 9:50 PM
	To: rest-discuss
	Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Res=
ource Discovery
	
	
	From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
	>
	> H=
uh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't
appropriate... don't know
	=
> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods
were
	> all=
owed...
	> This seems like the best approach so far.
	>
	>
	> Here's the te=
xt from the RFC. The only downside is responses
are not
	> cacheable.
	>
	>=
 [deleted]
	>
	
	Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I a=
m
wondering if
	they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems =
that
caching
	would have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee =
the
metadata in
	the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of =
time
(which is
	effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially
u=
seless...
	
	WRT this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a
re=
sponse back
	indicating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no
=
guarantee that
	the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment late=
r
when you do
	your actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decis=
ion
on the
	returned metadata a day later would be little different than
ma=
king a
	decision on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's
me=
tadata
	changed between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the
cli=
ent
	submitted a request based on the returned metadata, the server
would/s=
hould
	return the appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the
client=
 to
	request the OPTIONS again and see what has changed...
	
	---
	Seairth =
Jacobs
	seairth@...
